definition: to give the green light/to give the go-ahead

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
green
lamp/light/lantern/CL:盞|盏[zhan3]

sentences.english: Copenhagen will provide the green light for green growth.
sentences.chinese: 哥本哈根将为绿色增长大开绿灯。

sentences.english: He said that the release of the men gave the green light to terrorism.
sentences.chinese: 他说，释放这些人，等于向恐怖主义活动开绿灯。

definition: to open the back door/fig. under the counter/to do a secret or dishonest deal/to let sth in by the back door
lit. to enter by the back door/fig. to gain influence by pull or unofficial channels/back door or under the counter connections
lit. to drill a hole/to take advantage of a loophole/to exploit an advantage/to seize the opportunity (esp. to do sth bad)
to intercede/to plead for sb else
covert activities (election rigging etc)/under-the-table manipulations/black operations
to examine and approve/to endorse
see 冒大不韙|冒大不韪[mao4 da4 bu4 wei3]
pinyin: mao4 tian1 xia4 zhi1 da4 bu4 wei3

definition: to pass a message
to thwart/to obstruct (sth)
official authority used for private interests (idiom); to attain private ends by abusing public position
to give orders/to spread news or rumors/to leak certain information intentionally
to take risks
to untie/(fig.) to ease restrictions
to use one's position for personal gain (idiom)
to permit/to allow
lit. to make sb wear tight shoes (idiom)/to make life difficult for sb
